title: Emmett Johnson is on pace to become an elite running back
text:
Emmett Johnson has been impressive through two seasons in Nebraska’s backfield. The junior running back’s journey has been intriguing during his time in Lincoln. To become an elite running back in today’s landscape of college football, the ability to run and catch is as important as ever.
Below will be a comparison of Johnson to three former Husker running backs [Ameer Abdullah, Rex Burkhead and Roy Helu] with their statistics through their first two seasons in Lincoln.
Here are the rushing numbers:








Is Emmett Johnson on pace to be in the same realm of these former Husker RBs with his rushing numbers?


Through two seasons, the stats say yes

By: Bobby Schneider | Source: sportsreference.com








It’s clear that Johnson is on the right pace through to seasons. The 4.9 average yards-per-carry is right with Abdullah and Burkhead. Helu had a 5.9 average, but his amount of carries was significantly less than Abdullah, Burkhead and Johnson.
The total rushing yardage Johnson comes in third, just three yards above Helu, but once again, the amount of carries is less than Abdullah and Burkhead. There were numerous times over the last two seasons where Johnson would get minimal touches.
Moreover, Johnson’s rushing touchdowns were less than each of the three running backs he’s compared to, yet Nebraska’s offense as a whole was less productive during Johnson’s two seasons getting carries.
The receiving numbers set Johnson apart. Here are the receiving statistics for Johnson, Burkhead, Abdullah and Helu through two seasons:









Johnson’s redshirt freshman season he only had 46 receiving yards, but looking at his sophomore campaign, he tore it apart. Johnson jumped his receiving yardage to 286 as a sophomore wearing the scarlet and cream.
The top two red dots in the upper right corner show the jump that Johnson made in his second season. He had the best of the three in total receiving yards out of the backfield with 332 yards racked up through the air.
So, how does Johnson’s rushing and receiving put together compare?
Here are the all-purpose yards produced for each of the four running backs:









Johnson’s a little behind Abdullah and Burkhead through two years but is above Helu for all-purpose yardage, but he’s on the right road. In conclusion, Johnson is within spitting distance in some categories, and some ahead.
Overall, the junior Husker running back should be set to have quite the breakthrough junior season in Nebraska’s backfield. It will be intriguing to compare Johnson to these three after his junior season. The rushing yardage might not reach the other three, but the all-purpose very well could, with Johnson’s ability to catch the ball out of the backfield.

library(gt)


HuskerRBs <- read_csv("EJ_project.csv")

Delimiter: ","
chr  (6): Name, Season, Team, Conf, Class, Pos
dbl (15): G, Att, RushYds, RushAvg, RushTD, RYPG, Rec, RecYds, RecAvg, RecTD...

ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



head(HuskerRBs)

# A tibble: 6 × 21
  Name   Season Team  Conf  Class Pos       G   Att RushYds RushAvg RushTD  RYPG
  <chr>  <chr>  <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl>
1 Johns… 2023   Nebr… Big … FR    RB       12    90     411     4.6      2  34.3
2 Johns… 2024   Nebr… Big … SO    RB       13   117     598     5.1      1  46  
3 Johns… BothS… Nebr… Big … Total RB       25   207    1009     4.9      3  34.8
4 Burkh… 2009   Nebr… Big … FR    RB        9    81     346     4.3      3  38.4
5 Burkh… 2010   Nebr… Big … SO    RB       14   172     951     5.5      7  67.9
6 Burkh… BothS… Nebr… Big … Total RB       23   253    1297     5.1     10  56.4
# ℹ 9 more variables: Rec <dbl>, RecYds <dbl>, RecAvg <dbl>, RecTD <dbl>,
#   RecYPG <dbl>, Plays <dbl>, APYds <dbl>, APAvg <dbl>, APTD <dbl>



Rush_Stats <- HuskerRBs |>
  select(Class, Name, Att, RushYds, RushAvg, RushTD)


Rush_Stats |> 
  gt() |>
  cols_label(
    RushYds = "Rushing Yards",
    RushAvg = "Average YPC",
    RushTD = "Rushing TDs",
    Name = "Athlete",
    Class = "Year",
    Att = "Rush Attempts"
  ) |>
  tab_header(
    title = "Is Emmett Johnson on pace to be in the same realm of these former Husker RBs?",
    subtitle = "Through two seasons, the stats say yes" ) |>
      tab_style(
        style = cell_text(color = "black", weight ="bold", align = "left"),
        locations = cells_title("title") )  |>
          tab_style(
    style = cell_text(color = "red", align = "left"),
    locations = cells_title("subtitle")
      )

title: About
text: Bobby Schneider is a junior at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, studying sports media and communications. Schneider is a sports journalist who primarily covers Husker football and baseball.
